article.title: High-frequency bounds for the Helmholtz equation under parabolic trapping and applications in numerical analysis

response:
## Figure 1.1 Quiz

**Which of the following figures depicts parabolic trapping?**

A. Figure 1.1(a)
B. Figure 1.1(b)
C. Figure 1.1(c)
D. None of the above

**Correct Answer:** C. Figure 1.1(c)


## Equation (1.6) Quiz

**The resolvent estimate for parabolic trapping by obstacles, as stated in equation (1.6), shows a:**

A. Logarithmic loss over the nontrapping estimate
B. Exponential growth through a sequence of wavenumbers
C. Polynomial loss over the nontrapping estimate
D. No loss over the nontrapping estimate

**Correct Answer:** C. Polynomial loss over the nontrapping estimate


## Figure 1.4 Quiz

**In Figure 1.4, what does the vector field Z represent?**

A. The direction of the incident wave
B. The direction of the scattered wave
C. The direction of energy propagation
D. A specifically chosen vector field used in the proof of the resolvent estimate

**Correct Answer:** D. A specifically chosen vector field used in the proof of the resolvent estimate


## Equation (1.27) Quiz

**What does equation (1.27) represent?**

A. The Helmholtz equation in the exterior domain
B. The Sommerfeld radiation condition
C. A boundary integral equation for the Neumann trace of the solution
D. A variational formulation of the scattering problem

**Correct Answer:** C. A boundary integral equation for the Neumann trace of the solution


## Table 6.1 Quiz

**According to Table 6.1, what is the known upper bound for the inverse of the combined-potential operator,  (A<sub>k,η</sub>)<sup>-1</sup>, in the case of an Ikawa-like union of convex obstacles?**

A. 1
B. log(2 + k)
C. k
D. exp(αk)

**Correct Answer:** B. log(2 + k)
